title: MAJOR user friendliness issue with Evelynn THAT CAN EASILY BE FIXED!!!
body:
After initially casting her q, it can then be used 3 more times quickly. Its very annoying to have to click q EVERY TIME to activate the 3 launches. All game, all I'm doing is none stop clicking q as fast as I can pretty much.

PLEASE change this to PRESS AND HOLD. If I want to launch all 3 as fast as possible, I just press and hold. If I want to do it one at a time, I can still just click once for every launch. So easy to implement, yet will greatly improve her user friendliness.

Upvote so Riot sees thanks!

It has a minimum delay between each cast.

Most people **can** already hit that limit pretty easily. I personally end up hitting it nearly twice in the time it takes for the cast time to finish.

if you smash the cast button 3 times in the time its allowed to cast it once its still slower than maximum speed since the odds of you hitting the button at the exact time its ready to be cast is, well, pretty much impossible.

It's a QoL change.

Just popping in here as the playtester who worked on Evelynn.

We didn't try this on Evelynn but we suspected that players would've liked the button mashy input and wanted to keep it. We did experiment with the press and hold input on other content and found that it was generally unsatisfying.

While I agree that pushing the button is more satisfying in general, I think the case on Evenlynn is a SPECIAL case. On top of my mind right now, I don't think there is actually another champ that requires you to spam an ability AS OFTEN AS Eve's q, don't think anything comes close to it when compared. When you are jgling with her, all you are doing most of the time is using her q. That's what you are doing none stop and basically without a break. So as a result, over time it becomes annoying and exhausting on the finger, wears down the q key a lot, and becomes even more so if you play her often.

So I believe Eve is a special case due to the EXTRA amount of spam required on her q. I like Evelynn a lot, but the ONLY REASON I'm NOT playing her much is literally because of how annoying it is to use her q all game. Can you guys be kind enough to give this a second look, maybe change her in the next patch and see how people react to the change?  That would be much appreciated. The popularity of this post suggest overwhelming majority will like this change.

Thanks, and stay awesome! :)

Necessary Sample Size = (Z-score)2 * StdDev*(1-StdDev) / (margin of error)2
Here is an example of how the math works assuming you chose a 95% confidence level, .5 standard deviation, and a margin of error (confidence interval) of +/- 5%.

((1.96)2 x .5(.5)) / (.05)2
(3.8416 x .25) / .0025
.9604 / .0025
384.16 

385 correspondents needed.

As of the time of this response, 13.8k people viewed this post. The ratio of people who thumbs up and comment is in line with all other post, in other words, the amount of thumbs up accurately reflects the approval rating of 13.8k people.

2) Disagreement (Downvote: current count 9)
3) Doesn't care (No feedback provided) either because they don't play Eve or don't care either way (or have an alternative approach; I fall into this category, for example).

The problem you have right now, and why your assertion fails, is your sample isn't random (Boards users tend to be the vocal minority). However, your sample size is well over 385 correspondents (so you have a damned good sample size) so let's roll with it anyway.

If we look at your breakdown, you have an approval/disapproval/other percentage of:

0.70% / 0.07% / 99.23%

Either way, your assertion that you have overwhelming support is dubious at best.

Except look at the flavor of the ability. Warwicks Press and Hold feels good because it feels like you're biting and holding on to folk. If Evelynn Q was like a Leash ~~kinky~~ or similar to that, press and hold would have a corresponding effect that feels the same way. That's where the idea of satisfying comes into play, something that feels appropriate.

Push and Hold, to cast three instances of the same spell, is not cohesive together, as what we see, does not line up, with what we do. We Press and Hold, because we're holding on as Warwick. We hit that ~~like~~ button three times, and it fires off three attacks. They make sense, our body's action and our eyes perceiving it. 

Think about Pyke's Hold-Down-To-Charge. Just like how Pyke aims and charges his spear, you're holding it down the button to do so. You're matching his action with your own. It's satisfying.

One can just as easily argue that Evelynn is simply charging up whichever empowerment she gets after casting her Q, making the change potentially just as intuitive. Again, pontificating about whether or not such a mechanic would feel a certain way is in no way equivalent to actually testing the mechanic, particularly since quite a few people seem to be in favor of at least trying to see if it works.

No, not really, that's a really hard argument to make. You're ignoring the point made, where the action of the character, corresponds to the action of the player. Evelynn isn't charging up anything, she isn't holding on to anything. She lashes out spikes fast and quick. The action used to activate the ability does not match the ability itself.

You can reasonably the theory behind satisfying use, to determine what wouldn't feel a certain way. It's not "just try it, we'll see how it fits", this is how our brain reacts and perceives it.

It is you who are missing my point: as I said, Evelynn lashing out periodically could easily be a persistent or even a passive effect, for which a cast-and-hold mechanic may be argued to work. You are effectively attempting to reframe Evelynn's Q under a lens that would make such a change sound unintuitive, whereas I am doing the exact opposite. Since the matter is one of perception, which is inherently subjective, your point is moot.

No, I'm framing Evelynn's Q *As it actually is*. You throw something out, and you can tap it 3 additional times. I'm not changing anything. And, once again, you ignore what I'm saying. You send out three attacks, over three buttons.

You attack three times, three separate times. We see Evelynn attack 3 times. We do not see Evelynn holding onto something, or charging. We see three actions, come from our three actions. Each attack is separate. Look at other hold-charge buttons, like Xerath, Warwick, or Pyke, they have a single attack that comes from the push-hold. The action is One to One. 

It's not perception. This is quite literally psychology. And despite all your effort to look smart with your fancy words, you're still not getting it.
I'm not arguing for or against you, but you got a weird definition of psychology.

Again, you are imposing your own perception as some universal truth. For sure, Evelynn throws out a projectile, and then three follow-up spikes, but that does not mean that the model of four separate button presses is the only one that makes sense. One does not need to input an individual command for each autoattack, for example, and Ahri and Zoe's triple projectiles fly entirely on their own. It is not "quite literally psychology", it is you presuming your opinion is the only one that counts, while somehow still believing I am the one being arrogant in this exchange.

You've done nothing to actually pick apart any of my actual arguments. You ignore any of the points I've made about how Pyke, Xerath and Warwick are clear examples of how their abilities are built to feel like holding on or charging, and how Evelynn's Q doesn't compare. 

The point of a satisfying ability, comes from making it feel like what you did had a correlating effect. You press a button, something on screen happens. Xerath charges up his range, and the player, who holds down the button feels the very same thing. He's holding down his button, and Xerath will only fire when he lets go. It's Cause and Effect. It's more satisfying to see what happens, come from an action that correlates. Evelynn firing off 3 spikes from a single button hold, doesn't follow Xerath's example of what it means to hold a button. She's doing it independently of you, Xerath relies on you letting go. 

Your Ahri and Zoe example, makes zero sense. Take anyone who looks blindly at those abilities, and they'll tell you they pressed the button once (in Zoe's case, activated a Summoner Spell but same thing). Look at Pyke holding his trident, and it's clear it's being charged up. Why? Because they don't have any animations that accompany those projectiles. Evelynn does, her hand movements. Correlating action with animation with the button press. 

And yes, it's psychology. Games are built around psychology. What makes a game or a character feel good to play, is entirely psychology. In it's most primitive form of Blitzcrank: You land a hook, you feel good, you've accomplished an uncertain goal, and you've been rewarded by your brain. What makes a button/ability satisfying to press *Is all in your brain*. It's psychology, in one form or another.
